text: (upbeat music)

- I am Sarah Storelli, on a
quest to discover the people

behind the cutting edge
innovations across industries,
to tell the stories that define them
far more than their titles.
My guest today is Olivia Peterson.
Well, thanks so much, Olivia,

for being here with me
on the vodcast today.
Greatly appreciate it.
- Yeah, thank you for having me, Sarah.

I'm really excited to have
a conversation with you,
and also just to share some of my stories
and experiences here at Amazon.
- Amazing.
Let's dive in.
My first question for you today

is who has inspired you the
most along your journey?
- Yeah, I've been fortunate to have
a number of leaders who've inspired me.
However, I think what forms, you know,

so many of our early impressions
and goals starts at home.
So I would say, you know, my mother,
in the sense that she had a career.
Just seeing her be able to balance that
with motherhood, I think that's inspiring,
and kind of set the bar there.

But also just the diligent
and tenacious work ethic

that she had really
instilled that into me.

But then I would say I had,
you know, the great pleasure

of even early on in my career,
having some great leaders

who also just set the
right precedent for me,
in terms around like what you focus on,
what's most important,

how to be a pragmatic
and thoughtful leader.
And really, you know, where to dive deep,
and really understanding those signals.

So I'd say in each of
the different chapters,

and I always think of a career
being a chapter of decades.

So in each of those decades,
I've had the opportunity
to really be inspired by and developed by,
you know, some fantastic leaders.

And I would say, you know,
Dave Levy, I'll make a plug,

is one who I would definitely
count here at Amazon.
Just, you know, the level of humility,
but also just real customer obsession
and driving with that is really inspiring,

and it's actually what
brought me here to Amazon too.
- That's amazing.
Well, I agree.
And to that point, which is your favorite

Amazon leadership principle
out of all of them, and why?

- Well, I originally
was a customer of AWS,

so I especially appreciate
customer obsession.
And as a customer, I felt that.
So understanding how really
just that work backwards process too

is about driving towards
outcomes, how to be succinct.

And moving away, even from
those of us who kind of grew up

in a consulting capacity, which
is how I started my career,

you find that there's just
so many kind of fluffy angles
that you focus on.

And underlying all of
that is the real substance

of what needs to happen and
what the outcome needs to be.

And I would say something that
I've really taken from Amazon

and I was drawn to is
understanding what matters most
to the customer, staying focused on that
and really being obsessed about that.

Not as much about, you know,
some of the distractions
or noise in the environment,

but really staying focused
on what matters most.
So that is always my favorite.
- Agreed.

I know, I have noticed that
even in my personal life too.

All of a sudden, applying
the leadership principles,
being like, "What are you talking about?"
I'm like, "Oh, Amazon Brain."

You know, but they are
incredibly applicable,

really throughout all of
life in the various stages.
- And that's work backwards.
(both laugh)
- And deliver results.
- [Olivia] What is it you're trying to do?
Yes, exactly.
Exactly.

- You know, so given you
do run the, you know,

federal financial space,
I'd love to know from you

what generative AI opportunities
you think exist for it.
- Yeah, of course.

And this is a conversation
that is just amazing,

because these are
conversations that I'm having
with our customers at the board level,
and at the COO, the CEO, the president,
because they understand this is something
that is gonna be assistive technology
for their entire workforce,
but also an opportunity to reimagine.

And some examples that I see
immediately coming into play.
One, in terms of fighting financial crime.

Financial data is really a
matter of national security now.
I think we see that just by way

of all of the global
events that are happening,

but also just in terms of
how you think about financing
of a lot of criminal activity.

And if we look at the
application of generative AI,
we already have great evidence

towards not only reducing
rates of false positives,
but also increasing the identification
of what needs to get investigated.
So some great examples
that we already have in production today,
VERIFIN, who is a NASDAQ company,

is leveraging this right
now for their investigations
in terms of wire fraud.
And they already have had a 25% reduction
in terms of false positives,

but a 250% increase around
tagging those incidents
that require investigation.
The other piece

is just hugely customized
customer experience.

They're able to get new
products and offerings
that are really tailored to their needs.

We had another financial
services customer, NatWest,
who leveraged this to really share out
some of their new product offerings.

As a result, they had a 900%
increase in applications
for high interest bearing accounts.
Because again, those might not be things

that people go looking for,
but when it's suggested to them
based off of their qualifications already,

it's something that
they're able to act on.
So that's really great.

And then of course, there's
so much around efficiencies.

And this is really where we're
seeing the first use case,
is internal efficiencies.

So I work across all of
our financial regulators.

There's so much in the way
of disclosure documentation
and other legal documents
that really need to be poured through

in order to synthesize whether
or not compliance exists,

or whether or not there are
areas for investigation.

A lot of that is what
we're seeing our customers,
also even going into the tax code

or other just really
onerous documentation,

to be able to summarize that,
bring main points together,

and also just be able
to identify compliance.

And again, all of these
technologies are assistive.

We don't see them as
replacing human element,

but they're really gonna
supplement it in a way

that the humans, the
analysts, can really focus on
those differentiated areas,
as opposed to combing through to identify

and spending all of their hours
in terms of where to look.

They spend that instead
really diving deep.

So I think there's gonna
be some great application.
And you know, it's really amazing
just how quickly we've seen it evolve.
But I think over the next year too,

we're going to see even more,
particularly as customers
are really getting their data in order
and harnessing the power of that data.
Because of course, everything with gen AI
starts with how clean and how organized
and how accessible your data is.
So there's a lot that we're doing now,

and I know that the use cases
are gonna continue to grow.
- That's amazing.
My goodness.
I mean, thank you for sharing.

I know it's be heavily
influential for our listeners.

Another question I have, so
given as a leader and at AWS,
you know, and a woman in the workplace,

and you touched upon this
a little bit, you know,

how important is that to
you also to be, you know,
inspiring the next generation,

or getting more women into
not only the workforce,
but in the technology space,
and even into, you know, fed fin?
- It's very important.
And you know, it has to start,
and it does start with how we recruit.
So at our DC Summit in June,

I launched our Women in
Federal Affinity Group.

And I'm really excited
because a lot of our customers

aren't necessarily able to
have their own affinity groups.
So while at Amazon,

we've been internally focused
in supporting each other.

This is something that
we're really opening up
to our customer communities.

And it's so important, not
only to support the networking

and the connection because
we are the minority,

but also to do that at
all phases of the career.

I have a daughter, so it's
really important to me too
that women of all ages don't see this
as something that's not for them.

So reinvent, as you
know, is a massive event.
And a goal that I have is one day
to stand in line at the ladies room,
because in the six years that I've gone,
that's the place that you get some quiet.
(both laugh)
Because there's no one in there.
So I think it is hugely important.
Because it's not only with women,
but just diversity in general,
is important to have different experiences

and different perspectives
that we're bringing in.
But also our customers are diverse, right?
And they need to see themselves in us.

So I think that that's
incredibly important.
So I'm really grateful for the fact

that we have the right
platform here at Amazon
to welcome others in.
We are supportive of that,
and we just need to pull someone else in
and pull someone else along.
I think that's really important.
- Now, that's amazing, again,
you know, thank you so much.

My final question for
you today is actually,

what do you want to be known
for to future generations?
- Yeah.

I always wanna be thought
of as kind, you know?
So I try to lead with kindness,
personally and professionally.
Assume positive intent

for the people that
you're interacting with.
I want to be remembered as a leader

who brought my authentic
self, who empowered others,
and maintain that focus on kindness

to create a psychologically
safe environment
for my team to thrive in.
And also for customers, you know,
to be that connective tissue.
I often refer to that with my team,
of "be the fascia."
(both laugh)
I've always, in my career, and you know,

my background was in
financial engineering,

so it was much more
business-focused initially,
and structured finance.

But then very quickly I found
there was this missing bridge
between tech speak and business speak.
And I found that that was something that,

not only did I enjoy
being that translator,
but I really enjoyed being the connector.
And so, you know, that's something
that I wanna be remembered as

is, you know, I helped each
person be better together.
- I love it.
Well, thank you so much, Olivia,
for all your responses today
and the wonderful information,
and even how, you know, the fed fin space

is helping our customers
fulfill their mission.

So thank you so much for
all that you're doing,
and especially even being a inspiration

for all women out there to
continue to move forward

and thank you for bringing
those of us along with you.
- Yeah, happy to.
Thank you, Sarah.
- Thank you.
